title: ‘Landslide’: Santana beats out Baker, Wu says, while Culpepper wins D7
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Henry Santana won reelection as Boston City Councilor at-large, defeating Frank Baker, with Mayor Wu's coalition support.
Rev. Miniard Culpepper won the District 7 City Council seat, succeeding Tania Fernandes Anderson after her resignation.
All incumbent district councilors retained their seats; Ruthzee Louijeune topped the at-large ballot with over 50,000 votes.

title: Jake Wilson to be Somerville’s next mayor, unofficial results show
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Jake Wilson received 11,185 votes to become Somerville's next mayor, according to unofficial election results.
Wilson's opponent, Willie Burnley Jr., received 9,054 votes and has conceded the mayoral race.
Key issues for Wilson include addressing Somerville's housing crisis, street safety, and increasing city service levels.

title: Lowell police seeking public’s help with details about fatal hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lowell police are investigating a fatal hit-and-run that happened on Oct. 30 on Chelmsford Street.
The victim was a woman who died after being taken to a hospital; her identity has not been released.
Police have identified the suspect vehicle but urge the public to provide more information by calling 978-937-3200.

title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Nonbinding Israel divestment ballot question passes in Somerville
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Somerville voters passed a nonbinding resolution to divest from companies supporting Israel with 55.7% approval.
Somerville for Palestine led the ballot initiative, gathering over 11,000 signatures amid opposition and legal challenges.
The initiative now calls for Somerville officials to divest from companies like Lockheed Martin and HP, according to organizers.

title: Tom Brady just revealed that his dog Junie is a clone of Lua, his deceased furry friend
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Tom Brady revealed his new dog Junie is a clone of his late dog Lua, who died in 2023.
Brady worked with Colossal Biosciences, a biotech company he invests in, to clone Lua using a blood sample.
Colossal Biosciences, which acquired Viagen, aims to advance cloning and de-extinction technologies for species preservation.

title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Michelle Wu re-elected as Boston Mayor, unopposed, securing over 91% of the vote with more than 30,000 ballots cast.
Wu's national profile rises after testifying to Congress on Boston's sanctuary policies and opposing Trump's immigration claims.
Wu has implemented fare-free bus lines in Dorchester and pursued rent stabilization efforts during her tenure as Mayor.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu is poised for a second term after running unopposed in Boston's general election.
Wu's key priorities have included housing affordability and climate goals, facing both support and criticism.
Residents are invited to suggest priorities for Mayor Wu's new term via a Boston.com survey or email.

title: ‘This is kidnapping — plain and simple’: ICE arrests 9 employees at Allston car wash
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Nine employees with work permits were detained by ICE agents at the Allston Car Wash in a Tuesday morning raid.
Car wash manager claims agents detained employees before allowing them to retrieve documents due to language barriers.
Boston City Councilor Liz Breadon condemned the ICE raid, calling it 'kidnapping' and urging affected individuals to seek assistance.

title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots did not make any trades before the NFL deadline, keeping their current roster intact.
The Patriots recently traded players Keion White and Kyle Dugger, further reducing depth in their defensive lineup.
Despite a strong 7-2 start, the Patriots face potential depth challenges with injuries impacting key positions.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston restaurants and food businesses provide free meals and groceries amid SNAP benefit cuts during the government shutdown.
Options include free pizzas from American Flatbread and discounted meals at Joe Angelo’s for SNAP recipients in Boston.
Community fridges and donation drives by businesses like Brothers & Sisters Co. support those impacted by the SNAP delays.
